remarkable_women.name: Marie Curie
remarkable_women.summary: Pioneer of radioactivity and the first person to win Nobel Prizes in two sciences. She proved that persistence and curiosity can change the world.

remarkable_women.name: Ada Lovelace
remarkable_women.summary: Wrote the first published algorithm and imagined a future for computing beyond numbers. She is often called the first computer programmer.

remarkable_women.name: Katherine Johnson
remarkable_women.summary: NASA mathematician whose calculations helped send astronauts to orbit and the Moon. Her work showed the power of careful, accurate thinking.

remarkable_women.name: Jane Goodall
remarkable_women.summary: Studied chimpanzees in the wild and transformed how we understand animals. She also became a leading voice for conservation.

remarkable_women.name: Wangari Maathai
remarkable_women.summary: Started the Green Belt Movement and helped plant millions of trees. She showed that caring for nature can help communities thrive.

remarkable_women.name: Sally Ride
remarkable_women.summary: First American woman in space. She inspired generations of girls to explore science and engineering.

remarkable_women.name: Mae Jemison
remarkable_women.summary: First Black woman in space and a physician. She encourages kids to be both imaginative and rigorous.

remarkable_women.name: Rachel Carson
remarkable_women.summary: Marine biologist whose writing sparked the modern environmental movement. She showed that science and storytelling can protect life.

remarkable_women.name: Frida Kahlo
remarkable_women.summary: Artist who turned hardship into powerful self portraits. She celebrated identity, culture, and resilience.

remarkable_women.name: Wilma Rudolph
remarkable_women.summary: Overcame childhood illness to become an Olympic champion sprinter. Her story is a lesson in grit and belief.

remarkable_women.name: Sacagawea
remarkable_women.summary: Guided the Lewis and Clark expedition and helped build trust with native communities. She is remembered for courage and skill.

remarkable_women.name: Alice Paul
remarkable_women.summary: Leader of the US women's suffrage movement who helped secure the right to vote. She organized with patience and resolve.

space_facts.title: Olympus Mons
space_facts.body: The largest volcano in the solar system is on Mars. Olympus Mons is about three times taller than Mount Everest.

space_facts.title: Jupiter the Giant
space_facts.body: Jupiter is so big that more than 1,300 Earths could fit inside it. Its Great Red Spot is a giant storm.

space_facts.title: Venus Days
space_facts.body: A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus. It rotates very slowly but orbits the Sun faster.

space_facts.title: Saturn Rings
space_facts.body: Saturn's rings are made of ice and rock. Some pieces are tiny grains and others are as large as a house.

space_facts.title: The Moon
space_facts.body: The Moon is slowly drifting away from Earth at about 1.5 inches each year. This changes the length of our days.

space_facts.title: Milky Way
space_facts.body: Our galaxy has hundreds of billions of stars. It is a spiral galaxy with a bright central bulge.

space_facts.title: Mars Dust
space_facts.body: Dust storms on Mars can cover the entire planet. Some storms last for weeks.

space_facts.title: Neptune Winds
space_facts.body: Neptune has the fastest winds in the solar system, reaching over 1,000 miles per hour.

space_facts.title: Comets
space_facts.body: Comets are icy bodies that grow a glowing tail when they pass near the Sun. The tail always points away from the Sun.

space_facts.title: Asteroid Belt
space_facts.body: Most asteroids orbit between Mars and Jupiter. They are leftovers from the early solar system.

space_facts.title: Exoplanets
space_facts.body: Thousands of planets have been found around other stars. Some are rocky and some are gas giants.

space_facts.title: Sunlight
space_facts.body: Light from the Sun takes about 8 minutes to reach Earth. On Pluto it takes more than 4 hours.

wellness.title: Mindful Breathing
wellness.body: Try the 4-7-8 technique. Breathe in for 4, hold for 7, exhale for 8. Repeat four times to reset your nervous system.
wellness.quote: Almost everything will work again if you unplug it for a few minutes, including you.
wellness.author: Anne Lamott

wellness.title: Morning Light
wellness.body: Step outside for a few minutes of natural light. It helps your body clock and improves focus for the day.
wellness.quote: The sun is new each day.
wellness.author: Heraclitus

wellness.title: Tiny Walks
wellness.body: Take a 10 minute walk after meals. Small movement adds up and helps with energy and mood.
wellness.quote: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.
wellness.author: Lao Tzu

wellness.title: Water First
wellness.body: Drink a glass of water before coffee. Hydration supports attention and reduces afternoon fatigue.
wellness.author: Buddha

wellness.title: Stretch Break
wellness.body: Set a timer every hour to stretch for 60 seconds. It eases tension and helps posture.
wellness.quote: It is health that is real wealth.
wellness.author: Mahatma Gandhi

wellness.title: Slow Meals
wellness.body: Chew slowly and notice flavors. Mindful eating helps digestion and reduces stress.
wellness.author: Ram Dass

wellness.title: Quiet Minute
wellness.body: Pause for one minute of silence. Notice your breath and relax your shoulders.
wellness.quote: Silence is a source of great strength.
wellness.author: Lao Tzu

wellness.title: Gratitude List
wellness.body: Write down three good things each day. This trains your mind to notice what is working.
wellness.quote: Gratitude turns what we have into enough.
wellness.author: Aesop

riddles.question: I have cities but no houses. I have mountains but no trees. What am I?
What has hands but cannot clap?
What gets wetter as it dries?
What has a neck but no head?
What can travel around the world while staying in one corner?
What has keys but cannot open locks?
What has one eye but cannot see?
What has a face and two hands but no arms or legs?
